page.title: 19The History of Eccleshall
page.content: Following the{Norman Conquest,}Eccle- shall Manor was held by the Bishop of Lichfield and Chester, with other lands held by Robert of Stafford, from whom they again became subdivided among the Normans. A church is believ- ed to have stood here 300 years prior to this, and probably accounts for the name derivation ("meadowland next to a church"). Lying midway between Lich- field and Chester, Eccleshall was ideally suited for the building of a bishop's castle; most of the town's subsequent history revolves round these ecclesiastical connexions. A number of bishops are buried here. During the{civil wars}the castle was held in siege by the Parliamentary force garrisoning it, and they later partly demolished it. After the rest- oration the stones were used to build the present house, privately owned.
